/ #Forum Page Forum Forum What are the most common job interview questions and how should I answer them? Dance The Night Away :D 1 3 hours ago
/ #Forum Details Page
So I\'m going to attend my first ever interview for a job tomorrow. What are the tricky interview questions and how to answer them.
Answer What is love? :( 2 hours ago
While it is important to review the most common interview questions, I would also take a look at a \"Performance, Self-Review\" critique of your work. Responses below are specific to the academic field of research I have been involved in for the last 5 years.
1. What projects have you enjoyed working on the most, and why?
A: Some of my most highlighted work here at University has been working as a Researcher for a pediatric hematology/oncology study for sickle cell. I had the opportunity to sit down with patients, consent, and administer surveys about their experience as a patient. During this study, I also learned that patients who transition from pediatric care to adult get lost in transition. To address this, I facilitated monthly team meetings with providers, nurses, and social workers from both the adult and pediatric clinic twice a month to ensure data is being reviewed, voicing any concerns, and ensuring patients who are on study are frequently followed up with. We achieved a high retention rate, and even managed to get several of our on study subjects to attend a fall retreat for sickle cell.
2. What projects are you most proud of?
A: The first project I took on as a Researcher was for a Dermatology outpatient sunscreen study. I worked alongside a PI who gave me the responsibility of recruiting 60 Hispanic women for a sponsored skin study. I developed multiple recruitment strategies, and successfully recruited the enrollment goal within the recruitment window. Additionally, I learned how to utilized skin measuring devices, and also camera-software to capture images of each patient visit.
3. What are the things you have learned?
A: Coming up on 5 years, I have learned about the type of work I prefer doing as a researcher. Finding a balance between patient interaction and data entry is important. The healthy social interaction, and emphasizing the data collection are two-fold, yet I would like to be able to meet and develop a relationship with a patient prior to looking through medical charts.
4. What are some things you would have done differently looking back?
A: I was assigned to an observational study in the PICU to look at the epidemiology of bleeding. I went from room to room and spoke with nurses to see if there was any bleeding; whether it was from moderate to severe. I was being asked to classify the type of bleeding, quantify the amount of bleeding, and check ordered meds for each patient who bled. Initially, I struggled with being able to interpret the information I was being asked to collect. Because of this, my time commitment for this study increased and other studies I was assigned to struggled temporarily. Eventually, I called a meeting with my supervisor to come up with a solution — and we decided on adding other researchers to this study. Instead of working longer hours, and committing more time to this study, I would have mentioned something sooner rather than later about the time allocated to this study. Ideally, working smarter and not harder to remediate a situation as the one illustrated would be useful in this circumstance.
5. What has your boss done to help you do your job better? What could they do differently?
A: My supervisor was great when it came to answering any relevant questions when it related to the IRB. If I needed any guidance on how to submit a continuing review, do a study status update through RAMS-IRB, or needed to develop an amendment I learned how to do it the day of typically. My level of involvement in site feasibility meetings was very minimal, and for a suggestion I would recommend ensuring assigned CRCs such as myself was involved in the start-up process with the PI and along with the sponsor funding the research.
/ #Courses Page Courses Courses You currently have not subscribed to any courses My Courses Suggested Courses Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python Programming Language 35 Lectures
Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python Kamado Tanjiro Subscribe Subscribed Learn Python Programming the Easy Way!
If you want to learn how to write Python programs that can be used on Linux, Mac, and Unix operating systems, code python like a pro, solve real-world problems, or automate repetitive and complex tasks, click the subscribe button! What You Will Learn How to prepare your computer for programming in Python. Suggested text editors and integrated development environments to use when coding in Python. How to work with various data types including strings, lists, tuples, dictionaries, booleans, and more. How to define and use functions. Important built-in Python functions that you will use often. What modules are, when you should use them, and how to create your own. How to organize your Python programs - Learn what goes where. Lecture 1 - What is computation? Slides (PDF)
